title-part.text: DEVICES FOR FASTENING OR SECURING CONSTRUCTIONAL ELEMENTS OR MACHINE PARTS TOGETHER, e.g. NAILS, BOLTS, CIRCLIPS, CLAMPS, CLIPS, WEDGES, JOINTS OR JOINTING

note.note-paragraph:
Attention is drawn to: the Note following group E04B 1/38; the following places:
A44B Buckles, slide fasteners
A47G3/00 Ornamental heads for nails, screws, or
the like
B42F3/00 Means, not using staples, for attaching
sheets temporarily together
C14B17/08 Fastening devices, e.g. clips for leather-
stretching used in apparatus or machines
for manufacturing or treating skins,
hides, leathers or furs
E01B9/10 Screws or bolts for railway sleepers
E01B11/00 Rail joints
E04 Connections for building
E04D13/08 Clamping means for down pipes for roof
drainage
E04G5/04 Fastening scaffolds against buildings
E04G7/00 Scaffolding couplings
E05C Bolts for fasteners for wings, specially
for doors or windows
F16C29/10 Locking bearings for parts moving only
linearly
F16G17/00 Hooks as integral parts of chains
F16L Pipe joints
F16L3/00 Supports for pipes, cables or protective
tubing, e.g. hangers, holders, clamps,
cleats, clips, brackets
F16L33/02 Clips for connecting hoses to rigid
members
H01F7/00 Magnetic holding devices
H02N13/00 Electrostatic holding devices.
Groups F16B2/00 to F16B47/00 take precedence over group F16B1/00.

The following IPC groups are not used in the CPC scheme. Subject matter covered by these groups is classified in the following CPC groups:
F16B7/08 covered by F16B5/12, F16B7/04, F16L3/00

F16B7/16 " " F16B7/14
F16B13/10 " " F16B13/08
F16B13/13 " " F16B13/002, F16B13/12
F16B21/14 " " F16B21/12, F16B21/125
F16B25/02 " " F16B25/00
F16B25/04 " " F16B25/00
F16B25/06 " " F16B25/00
F16B25/08 " " F16B25/00
F16B33/04 " " F16B33/02
F16B37/10 " " F16B37/0842, F16B37/0871

CPC-specific-text.text: Joining sheets, plates or panels in abutting relationship
by moving the sheets, plates or panels substantially in their own plane, perpendicular to the abutting edge
a tongue on the edge of one sheet, plate or panel co-operating with a groove in the edge of another sheet, plate or panel

using I-shaped connectors

and using expanding clamps

by using permanent deformation

fastened over the edges of the sheets or plates

title-part.text: heads of bolts or screws for rotations by a tool

CPC-specific-text.text: characterised by the shape of the recess or the protrusion engaging the tool
substantially rectangular, e.g. one-slot head
substantially cross-shaped
star-shaped or multi-lobular, e.g. Torx-type, twelve-point star
substantially prismatic with up to six edges, e.g. triangular, square, pentagonal, Allen-type cross-sections
having one eccentric circular or polygonal recess or protrusion
with a conical or prismatic recess for receiving a centering pin of the tool apparatus
with grooves, notches or splines on the external peripheral surface designed for tools engaging in radial direction
with holes to be engaged with corresponding pins on the tool or protruding pins to be engaged with corresponding holes on the tool
causing slipping of the tool in loosening rotation, i.e. disabling unscrewing unless another tool is used
with a threaded engagement between the head of the bolt or screw and the tool
with a head engageable by two or more different tools

title-part.text: Screws that cut thread in the body into which they are screwed, e.g. wood screws

reference.text: F16B35/065 takes precedence; joining sheets or plates using screws with two separate threads F16B5/0275, using screws with adjustment sleeves F16B5/0283

CPC-specific-text.text: of the helical wire type
characterised by the material of the body into which the screw is screwed
the material being a soft organic material, e.g. wood or plastic
the material being metal, e.g. sheet-metal or aluminium
the material being a hard non-organic material, e.g. stone, concrete or drywall
the screw being designed to be screwed into different materials, e.g. a layered structure or through metallic and wooden parts
characterised by geometric details of the screw
characterised by the geometry of the thread, the thread being a ridge wrapped around the shaft of the screw
the ridge being characterised by its cross-section in the plane of the shaft axis
the ridge having indentations, notches or the like in order to improve the cutting behaviour
the screw having distinct axial zones, e.g. multiple axial thread sections with different pitch or thread cross-sections
with a non-threaded portion on the shaft of the screw
with multiple-threads, e.g. a double thread screws
characterised by its pitch, e.g. a varying pitch
with a shaft of non-circular cross-section or other special geometric features of the shaft
characterised by geometric details of the tip
the screw having wings
the screw being assembled or manufactured from several components, e.g. a tip out of a first material welded to shaft of a second material

title-part.text: Screws performing an additional function to thread-forming, e.g. drill screws

CPC-specific-text.text: or self-piercing screws
by means of a drilling screw-point, i.e. with a cutting and material removing action
by means of a self-piercing screw-point, i.e. without removing material
